1954–present |country={{flag|Australia|23px}} |allegiance= |branch=[[File:Australian Army Emblem.JPG|25px]] [[Australian Army]] |type=Training Establishment |role=All corps officer and NCO training |size= |command_structure=Royal Military College of Australia |current_commander= |garrison= |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles= |notable_commanders=[[Ted Serong]] |anniversaries= |decorations= |battle_honours= |identification_symbol=[[File:Land Warfare Centre unit colour patch.PNG|100px]] |identification_symbol_label=[[Unit Colour Patch]] |identification_symbol_2= |identification_symbol_2_label= }} The '''Land Warfare Centre''' (LWC) is an [[Australian Army]] training establishment that is responsible for the provision of promotion courses to [[Officer (armed forces)|commissioned]] and [[non commissioned officer]]s (NCOs) in an "all corps" setting. It was originally established during [[World War II]] at [[Canungra, Queensland]], as the Jungle Training Centre to prepare troops for combat in the [[South West Pacific Area]]. During the 1950s and 1960s, the centre fulfilled a similar role, but since then has evolved to provide a broader spectrum of training courses with detachments at a number of bases across Australia. ==Structure== Under the higher Royal Military College of Australia formation, LWC has its headquarters at [[Canungra]], [[Queensland]], and consists of a number of wings, namely: Officer Training Wing (OTW), the Warrant and Non Commissioned Officer Academy (WONCO) and Education Wing. OTW is located at [[Kokoda Barracks]] at Canungra, while Education Wing is headquartered at [[Simpson Barracks]] in Melbourne. Headquarters WONCO is co-located with LWC headquarters, but has detachments spread throughout Australia at [[RAAF Edinburgh]], [[Steele Barracks (Moorebank)|Steele Barracks]], Simpson Barracks, [[Gallipoli Barracks]], [[Lavarack Barracks]], and [[Robertson Barracks]]. Education Wing has small detachments at each of these locations, and also at [[Leeuwin Barracks]] in Western Australia.{{cite web |url=http://www.army.gov.au/Who-we-are/Divisions-and-Brigades/Forces-Command/Royal_Military_College_of_Australia/Land-Warfare-Centre |title=Land Warfare Centre |publisher=Australian Army |accessdate=27 August 2012}} ==History== The training centre draws its lineage from the Jungle Training Centre that was formed in November 1942 in response to the requirement to train troops for jungle combat in the [[South West Pacific Area]] during [[World War II]].{{harvnb|Dennis|Grey|Morris|Prior|1995|p=136}}. Under the command of Colonel [[Alex Bath MacDonald|Alex MacDonald]], who had previously commanded the [[Darwin Mobile Force]], the centre grew out of the Guerilla Warfare School that had been established earlier at [[Foster, Victoria]].{{harvnb|Trigellis-Smith|1992|p=146}}. Located in the [[Gold Coast hinterland]] below the [[Beechmont, Queensland|Beechmont]] plateau that stretches towards [[Tamborine Mountain]], the establishment was located amidst thick rainforest and steep, razor-back country.{{harvnb|Ham|2007|p=176}}. Staffed by instructors that had experienced combat – mostly in the Middle East, initially, but then in New Guinea as the war progressed{{harvnb|Brune|2004|p=117}}. – upon creation the centre consisted of a number of detachments including the Reinforcement Training Centre, the Independent Company Training Centre and the Tactical School. As the demand for specialised jungle warfare training grew with Australia's increased involvement in the Pacific, the centre was expanded until it consisted of about 2,000 trainees organised into eight training [[Company (military unit)|companies]]; each week a total of 500 personnel marched out to join the infantry battalions fighting in the [[New Guinea campaign]] having completed a four-week course. In addition, the Commando Training Battalion was formed to provide reinforcements for the [[Australian commandos|Australian commando]] units, while an officer training wing focused upon delivering specialised [[platoon]]-level training for officers over the course of a six-week program. After May 1943, the centre began to contract as its need declined, although it continued to train large numbers of soldiers under experienced senior instructors such as Major [[Harry Harcourt]].{{harvnb|Trigellis-Smith|1992|p=151}}. It was finally disbanded in 1946 following the conclusion of hostilities. [[File:AWM 060650 Jungle Training Centre Canungra November 1943.jpg|right|thumb|Australian soldiers undertaking bayonet training at Canungra, November 1943]] The mid-1950s saw the Australian Army deployed to a number of theatres in Southeast Asia in response to the threat of Communism and as a result the Jungle Training Centre was re-raised in 1954.{{harvnb|Horner|Bou|2008|p=156}}. At that time the centre's facilities were expanded to over {{convert|7700|acres}} and its subunits consisted of an officer and NCO training unit, a collective pre-deployment training unit and a doctrine wing. Colonel [[Ted Serong]] took over command of the centre in 1955 and instructors included officers who had gained considerable experience during World War II; these included Lieutenant Colonel George Warfe, who had commanded a commando company and infantry battalion during the war and who was appointed to the role of Chief Instructor. Major Bernard O'Dowd, who had served in [[Korean War|Korea]], took over as Senior Instructor.{{harvnb|Robins|2012|p=64}}. Using the skills of these men, the units of the [[Royal Australian Regiment]] were prepared for tours of [[Malayan Emergency|Malaya]] and [[Indonesia–Malaysia confrontation|Borneo]]. The first unit to receive training was the [[2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment]], which cycled through Canungra in company lots starting in early 1955.{{harvnb|Horner| Bou|2008|p=106}}. In 1960, the centre's remit was expanded to include the provision of training on promotion courses for officers of all corps in the Army.{{harvnb|Dennis|Grey|Morris|Prior|1995|pp=136–137}}. In 1964, the centre came under the command of Colonel [[Stuart Clarence Graham]].{{harvnb|Ham|2007|p=302}}. Following the commitment of Australian personnel to [[Vietnam War|South Vietnam]], the centre ramped up its training program as 10,000 soldiers were rotated through Canungra each year as part of the pre-deployment training each battalion had to complete before undertaking its tour of duty.{{harvnb|Dennis|Grey|Morris|Prior|1995|p=137}}.{{harvnb|Horner|Bou| 2008|p=161}}. As a part of this, on 4 January 1966, a demonstration platoon was raised at Canungra. It was later redesignated as HQ 1st Division Defence Company.{{harvnb|Horner|Bou|2008|p=155}}. Training during this time consisted of three weeks of physical and mental hardening through a battery of obstacle courses and battle inoculation ranges.{{harvnb|Ham|2007|p=177}}. Following the conclusion of [[Military history of Australia during the Vietnam War|Australia's involvement in the war]] in 1972, the Australian Army underwent a period of re-organisation that saw it move towards an "all volunteer" force. As a part of this restructure, in December that year the Australian government decided to reduce the nine regular infantry battalions to five, with a sixth battalion being established at Canungra at company strength, where it would fulfil the role of demonstration company before eventually being expanded into a full battalion.{{harvnb|Horner|Bou|2008|p=242}}. A lack of manpower, however, forced the disbandment of this company in 1973. The requirement for an [[opposing force]] remained, though, and so the [[10th Independent Rifle Company, Royal Australian Regiment]] (10 IRC) was raised on 23 May 1974, with an establishment of 60 personnel organised into two platoons. By the mid-1970s the focus of Australia's doctrine had moved away from "forward defence" in Southeast Asia towards the [[Defence of Australia policy|"defence of Australia"]] and, as a result, in June 1975 the Jungle Training Centre was renamed the "Land Warfare Centre". In 1980, the raising of the Operational Deployment Force, which required a battalion of the [[3rd Brigade (Australia)|3rd Task Force]] to be maintained at high readiness for deployment to the South West Pacific or Southeast Asia year-round, meant that the Army once again needed to develop skills necessary to operate in tropical or jungle conditions.{{harvnb|Horner|Bou|2008|pp=263–264}}. As a result, a renewed jungle warfare training program was established. Urban development around Canungra had encroached upon the training area, though, so the decision was made to situate this training in a new establishment called the 1st Division Tropical Training Centre (later redesignated to Battle School), at [[Tully, Queensland]].{{harvnb|Horner|Bou|2008|pp=266–267}}. The Land Warfare Centre therefore continued to focus on individual training rather than collective training and this in part led, in March 1980, to the reduction of LWC's demonstration force, the 10th Independent Rifle Company, to just one platoon of 40 men as its manpower was redirected to meet shortages in the 3rd Task Force.{{harvnb|Horner|Bou|2008|p=264}}. Throughout the early to late 1990s, the centre experienced a period of flux. 10 IRC was disbanded and the centre underwent a number of further name changes; in 1998 it adopted the designation as the "Army All-Corps Promotions Training Centre" in line with similar designations being used across Training Command, a very short lived designation as in 1999 it adopted the designation of the "Army Promotion Training Centre". Late the following year, as a result of a re-organisation of its higher formation – Training Command – the centre adopted the title of "Headquarters Regional Training Centres"; in line with this eight Regional Training Centres were raised. Formed from the old Training Groups, they were established in South Queensland, North Queensland, the Northern Territory, [[Australian Army Land Warfare Centre, Western Australia|Western Australia]], South Australia, Tasmania, Victoria and New South Wales. These became known as regional Wings of LWC in 2005. By 1 January 2009, the Tasmanian Wing had closed, as had the Western Australia Wing, with responsibility for both being passed to the South Australian Wing.{{cite news| title=LWC-WA disbanding |newspaper= Army: The Soldiers’ Newspaper |issue=1198 |date=18 September 2008|page=28| publisher= [[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence, Canberra]] | url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/armynews/editions/1198/1198.pdf|accessdate= 29 March 2010}}{{cite web| title= Foundation News |date=December 2007 – January 2008 |page=1| publisher= Army Museum of Western Australia Foundation | url=http://www.armymuseumwa.com.au/Refdocs/Foundation%20News%20Dec07-Jan08.pdf|accessdate= 1 April 2010}} In 2012, LWC became a subordinate unit of the Royal Military College of Australia formation and was training about 3,000 personnel each year across a suite of courses delivered to junior and senior non commissioned and junior commissioned officers. It also supports the [[Army Aboriginal Community Assistance Program]], detaching officers in command, leadership and management roles to implement the project's training serials.{{cite web |url=http://www.army.gov.au/Our-work/Community-engagement/ExSAUNDERS11 |title=Exercise Saunders 2011 |publisher=Australian Army |accessdate=11 August 2012}} ==Citations== {{reflist|4}} ==References== {{Refbegin}} *{{cite book|last=Brune |first=Peter |title=A Bastard of a Place: The Australians in Papua |year=2004 |publisher=Allen & Unwin |location=Crows Nest, New South Wales |isbn=978-1-74114-403-1|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Dennis|first=Peter|last2=Grey |first2=Jeffrey|authorlink2=Jeffrey Grey |last3=Morris |first3=Ewan |last4=Prior|first4=Robin|title=The Oxford Companion to Australian Military History|year=1995|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=0-19-553227-9 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Ham |first=Paul |title=Vietnam: The Australian War |year=2007 |publisher=HarperCollins |location=Pymble, New South Wales |isbn=978-0-7322-8237-0|ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Horner |first1=David |authorlink=David Horner |last2=Bou |first2=Jean |year=2008 |title=Duty First: A History of the Royal Australian Regiment |edition=2nd |location=Sydney, New South Wales |publisher=Allen & Unwin |isbn=978-1-74175-374-5 |ref=harv}} *{{cite journal |last=Robins |first=Darren |title=Colonel George Warfe, DSO, MC, MID |magazine=Australian Infantry Magazine |year=2012 |issue=April 2012 – October 2012 |location=Surfers Paradise, Queensland |publisher=Power Pacific International |pages=60–65|issn=1447-5545 |ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Trigellis-Smith|first=Syd|title=The Purple Devils: The 2/6 Australian Commando Squadron|year=1992|publisher=2/6 Commando Squadron Association|location=Melbourne|isbn=0-646-07125-4 |ref=harv}} {{Refend}} [[Category:Australian Army]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1942]]
